article-meta.product: Christians and War by ReimerA. James Facets. Fortress, Minneapolis, 2010. pp. $9.99. ISBN 978-8006-3819-1.

body.p: Reimer offers an accessible and fair presentation of the three classical Christian attitudes toward war: crusading or holy war, just war, and pacifism. His survey of Christian teachings and practices on issues of war, violence, and the state takes readers from classical Greco-Roman times to the present. Arguing that the church’s responses to war can only be understood through the church’s changing relationship to culture, Reimer concludes with an analysis of the contemporary debate and proposes criteria for legitimate and illegitimate use of force by nation-states.

title-group.article-title: Slavery as Moral Problem in the Early Church and Today

article-meta.product: Slavery as Moral Problem in the Early Church and Today by GlancyJennifer A. Facets. Fortress, Minneapolis, 2011. pp. $9.99. ISBN 978-8006-9670-2.

body.p: In this brief volume, Glancy tackles haunting questions: Why did Jesus not speak out forcefully against slavery? Why did the early church not see slavery as fundamentally incompatible with the gospel? Were there any bright moments when some Christians in fact drew that conclusion, and why do we not know more about them? Why did Christianity not have more of an impact on slaveholding in the Roman Empire? In an age when debt bondage, child labor, sex slavery, and human trafficking are increasing and increasingly integrated into economic globalization, what should our response be? And do early Christian writings provide any help at all?

body.p: The Blackwell Companions to Religion series presents a collection of the most recent scholarship and knowledge about world religions. Each volume draws together newly-commissioned essays by distinguished authors in the field, and is presented in a style that is accessible to undergraduate students, as well as scholars and the interested general reader. These books approach the subject in a creative and forward-thinking manner, providing a forum in which leading scholars in the field can make their views and research available to a wider audience.

article-meta.product: The Blackwell Companion to the New Testament edited by AuneDavid E. Blackwell Companions to Religion. Wiley-Blackwell, Chichester, West Sussex, UK, 2010. pp. $44.95 (cloth). ISBN 978-1-4051-0825-6.

body.p: Written by more than 40 scholars, this volume provides a detailed introduction to NT study. The early chapters consider the historical, social, and culture contexts in which the NT was produced, and examine relevant linguistic and textual issues. Later chapters treat the 27 books and letters of the NT systematically, each chapter beginning with a review of current issues and concluding with an annotated bibliography.
